Reviews.Title: Fujifilm HS-30 EXR
Reviews.Author: Michael T. McCaffrey "sumofan"
Reviews.Content: PREFACE:  This review is primarily intended for Point & Shoot types. I do not delve into MANUAL adjustments, nor do I have any interest in that. I want something that will take good pics without undue hassle and is convenient to take on travel.Well, after a fairly long wait for Fujifilm to release the HS-30, mine arrived this afternoon. I charged the li-on battery (no more four AAs) and took it outside to take around ten test shots. They turned out perfectly. I had the HS-10 ... then HS-20 before this latest incarnation, and really liked both cameras. I've no doubts I'll like this one at least, if not more, than the previous HS-20. You can read all the specs, etc., so I won't get into that. Physically, the electronic viewfinder and LCD are sharp, clear, and bright -  and I do detect that slight shortening of the flash unit, which protruded a bit annoyingly on the HS-20. Thus, no problem at all focusing with the manual lens (which I love). I also did not detect the lag one experienced between shots with the HS-20. Now, again, I just received the thing and only took some ten shots ... but I was very happy with the shots. Since mine is the first review, it remains to be seen if problems, such as the overheating warning with the past early editions of the HS-20 produced, will come along as others get their cameras and put them to use. I hope to get out there tomorrow and run this thing through its paces. If anything untoward happens, I will certainly advise. The HS-30, like the HS-20, sure beats the heck out of having to stop to change cumbersome lenses for differing shots/scenes! Additionally, it all fits into a nice/compact Case Logic case, no more lugging around all that other "stuff" in backpacks, etc.  :-)  In closing, my background is strictly amateur photography. I've no aspirations in becoming a pro. The pics I take are for my own enjoyment, and it ends there. Speaking only for myself, I do believe photography should be fun, not a hassle. I've had the Canon 7D and the 60D, with all the "L" lenses, so I do "know my way around the block" a bit. This is not to say I think this bridge camera takes the place of DSLRs for professional use, certainly not. Enjoy your HS-30, and please do post your experiences so we can all benefit.  :-)ADDED:  March 15, 2012:  Took the camera out to my favorite park and ran it through its paces. There was a slight ... slight ... delay between some shots at the park, but no delay when taking pics indoors and other environments. Not a problem for me.  I took 52 pictures, and except for two, they were absolutely perfect, and those two were probably my fault. The zoom works fine, no problems. The LCD is also excellent, though I prefer taking my shots via the viewfinder. Lastly:  I am a huge fan of POST PROCESSING any pictures I take, be it with a DSLR or the HS-30. I have a MAC and use APERTURE 3, and Aperture 3 makes a notable difference in getting pictures to look the way I want them (that "finishing touch"). If you're using a Windows machine, you might want to look into software packages designed to work with digital pictures.SUMMATION:  Realizing this camera is NOT a DSLR, I would buy it again in a heartbeat. It felt so nice to walk around the park this morning without lugging along a bag filled with heavy lenses. And the resulting pictures more than satisfy me.ADDED:  3-20:  Having had this camera since last week, and having taken a lot of shots with it, I can say I take nothing back: it was worth buying. I am speaking strictly from a Point & Shoot perspective here. If one is looking for all the bells and whistles of a DSLR, then get a DSLR, or you're probably gonna be frustrated. Reiterating: though quite advanced for a P&S;, this camera, in the end, is NOT a DSLR.ADDED/CONCLUSION: 5-2-12: I've now had the HS-30 for about 1.5 months and have used it extensively. I even took it on the annual trek to Las Vegas a bit over a week ago, and it performed flawlessly. If anything, I would draw the prospective buyer's attention to ACTION photography. I would NOT expect this to behave like a DSLR in this respect, OK? You CAN get a sequence using CONTINUOUS MODE, but I found using a DSLR in this respect (action shots of moving subjects) much more satisfying. Taking shots of static objects however, this camera has worked excellently. I note the price keeps dropping on what they were asking initially for the camera. I think it's a great bargain if you're in the market for a great Point and Shoot camera.

Reviews.Title: A winner for me!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: First, I want to compliment Amazon on the free shipping. I ordered the HS30 on April 9th and received it on April 14th. Two to five days before the estimated time it was supposed to arrive. ( between 16th and 19th ) Very pleased with that Amazon.So far I think the HS30 is great! The IQ is not bad at all. I have a Nikon d3100 which takes great pictures but sometimes I would miss a great shot because I didn't have the right lens on at the time. I took a closeup pic of a Finch on my porch railing yesterday that I never would have gotten with my Nikon, I'm sure, because I would have had to change lenses. The pic came out excellent! Crisp, sharp and detailed. Took a great pic of a quarter-moon this morning. Again, crisp, sharp, and closeup. Now, is every pic like that? No. But, neither is every pic taken with a $5,000 camera.Take time to go through the menus and learn the camera, and you should be fine. I mainly wanted the long lens and the panorama feature. So far so good. What persuaded me to buy this camera was I had previously owned the HS10 but had to return it for financial reasons, not because I didn't like it. When looking back at some of the pictures I had taken with it, which were pretty good, (not my photography skills but the camera IQ) and now being a little more experienced with shutter speed and aperture settings and such, I figured this time around I could really work some magic with it.Also, a nice surprise was that from the back it looks almost exactly like the D3100. So far, all of my macro shots have been really good too. Really good! Some hand-held telephoto ( at full zoom ) shots were a bit shaky but if you can use a tripod with remote or self-timer you should be good to go. The low-light shooting modes work pretty good too. IS works good.If you want a camera that you can take a picture, "now" without fumbling with a bunch of lenses and stuff and still get nice images, this should do the trick. Plus, there are a lot of different settings and so forth to play with. The 360 panorama works great. ( might need to practice a little ) The software has a 360 viewer which is pretty cool.Recommend as a nice carry around, all purpose, trip taking camera.

Reviews.Title: It didn't work for me, but it might work very well for others.
Reviews.Author: John Sturgeon
Reviews.Content: With high expectations the Fujifilm HS30 arrived yesterday on it's first day of release.  I tested it out yesterday afternoon. Today it went back to Amazon.  To be specific, the actual performance of the camera did not match everything the official spec sheet said it would do.  And there were a few other problems with it, too.Part 1 - THERE IS A LIMIT ON THE ISO / SHUTTER SPEED.Those of you who may have seen my Amazon post on the Canon SX40 will know that over the last five months and 22 pages of Comments and replies I have criticized Canon heavily for putting an unnecessary restriction on its ISO (The old-fashioned term for this was "film speed").  If you want to do low-light photography you have to be able to use a higher ISO and a slower shutter speed. That is the way it has always been for all types of cameras.Canon had placed a new, arbitrary limit of ISO 100 on the camera (which was not on its previous model, the SX30) together with maintaining its maximum 15-second shutter speed limit. This stopped me, briefly, from doing my long-standing, nighttime photography of Monterey Bay Harbor, which sometimes required an ISO 400 with a 15-second shutter speed. There was no way for the user to bypass this limit even in Full Manual Mode.The new Fujifilm HS30 has a similar limit, though it is not nearly as severe. To be fair, this limit on the HS30  is so slight that most people will probably never notice it at all.  But for those of you who may be effected by this ISO and Shutter speed limit, here it is.The Website makes no mention of it.  Download the .pdf file for the full User Manual for the HS30, and you will see only this small notation repeated both on pages 33 and 34."The shutter speed is restricted depending on the ISO setting."How much is it restricted?  The user manual does not say. I called Fujifilm tech support, and they didn't even know for sure.  So I tested the camera myself, and here is the ISO / shutter speed limit, exactly:ISO....100 = 30 second shutter speed limitISO....200 = 15 second shutter speed limitISO....400 = 8 second shutter speed limitISO....800 = 4 second shutter speed limitISO..1600 = 2 second shutter speed limitISO..3200 = 1 second shutter speed limitAlthough all of the publicity says that you can use shutter speeds "from 30 seconds through 1 / 3200 of a second," that is not quite literally true. You can only do that at ISO 100. If you try to do that at ISO 200, then the shutter speed limit is cut in half to 15 seconds.  At ISO 400 it is cut in half again to 8 seconds, and so on.Those of you who want a graphic example of what a limit on ISO means may wish to view my video I posted for the Canon SX40 here on Amazon.  At ISO 400 with a 15-second shutter speed there are some beautiful nighttime colors reflected from the light of Monterey Bay Harbor.  At ISO 100 with a 15-second shutter speed limit the picture is almost entirely dark.  The limit on the Fujifilm HS30 at ISO 400 is only 8 seconds, very close, but not quite enough for what I personally need.  If that effects you, fine, now you are aware of it. If not, then that's fine too. In which case please simply just ignore this whole part of my post as completely irrelevant to you personally.But be aware that in some modes on the HS30 you cannot use a shutter speed of longer than one quarter of a second.  That really isn't very much to work with if you are trying to do any time-exposure photography with this camera, especially nighttime long-exposures.  So at least now you know.Part 2 - THERE ARE A FEW OTHER PROBLEMS WITH IT, TOO.Shooting in low light at dim targets in the distance is like shooting blind in the dark if you cannot see what you are shooting at.  While the Fujifilm HS30 does have "live view" on the LCD, it does not have an "exposure" live view.*  Live view means you see on the LCD exactly what the camera sees. "Exposure" live view means you see on the LCD what the final picture will look like (how light or dark it will be) before you actually take the shot.  The LCD lightens and darkens as you adjust the dial.  Canon cameras do that. Fujifilm and Nikon cameras apparently do not.  (If I am wrong about this, however, then someone please correct this information for the benefit of everyone else reading this post.  Thank you.)* Technically called "exposure simulation live preview" or "exposure priority display."Trying to line up on a distant target in low light is fairly easy with an exposure live view LCD, since it lightens as the exposure setting increases.  If you want high definition in the shadows you simply raise the exposure.  If you want high definition in clouds, then you lower the exposure.  Combine the two images in Photoshop and you get an HDR photo (High Dynamic Range) with well defined clouds together with bright colors even in the shadows.  With the Fujifilm HS30 you have to guess ahead of time, take the shot and then look at the results afterwards to see if you got it right. On a camera with an "exposure" live view you already know fairly closely ahead of time what the result will be. I personally consider "exposure live view" superior to simply "live view" on the LCD of a camera, because it is simply more intuitive when you look at the LCD and see it for yourself.  It is especially important when shooting in low-light conditions since it makes it much easier just to find the actual shooting target, and is also very helpful for doing your own HDR photographs to finish yourself in Photoshop since with HDR you have to deliberately make some portion of each photo look lighter or darker in order to combine two opposites, but the judgment question will be, by how much exposure on each one?The Red Craftsman Toolbox Test.  The first poster here noted that there was some washout in the colors with his Fujifilm HS30, and I noticed a similar effect, but for me it depended on the angle of the light source. Here's how to test it for yourself.  Take an American-Flag-Red Craftsman toolbox and place it near an open window.  When I photographed it from the side, the color was accurate.  When I faced the window and shot directly toward the light source, the colors washed out considerably, and I noticed that the toolbox had shifted to a distinctive orange-red color.  A parallel test with a small Canon point-and-shoot camera (the SX150) showed no color washout and no similar color shift.  Photoshop can easily adjust for this, as the first poster noted, and the HS30 photos would have required that adjustment to them, but only to the ones where the camera was pointed directly toward the light source.Focussing Problems and Image Stabilization Problems. I had heard stories about focussing problems and image stabilization problems with Fujifilm cameras, and they all turned out to be true.  I shot from a tripod, from a makeshift beanbag rest (my Filson jacket rolled up) and also from a freestanding position.  The tripod shots did much better than the others by far, especially for image stabilization, but some of the others did not do very well at all, especially at much lower speeds of around one quarter of a second.  With the bean bag there was some double imaging with the HS30 (which did not show up with the little Canon SX150 by comparison.) Higher shutter speeds obviously worked much better for image stabilization, but in a variety of outdoor and indoor settings I used during the afternoon of that day I just could not get the camera to focus consistently at all. Even some of the well-stabilized shots were still slightly out of focus. To be fair, the shots that were in focus were much better photos on the Fujifilm HS30. No doubt about it.  Some of them were truly outstanding.  But also to be honest about it, less than half of all the shots I took were very clearly in focus at all, using both manual focus and auto focus. I just couldn't seem to get it quite right.I have heard that people who know how to adjust the focus well on a Fujifilm camera can work around this with much better results than I got. I certainly hope that is true.  And the little Canon SX150 is simply no match for the Fujifilm HS30 when it is focussing well.  A few of the shots with the HS30 were truly extraordinary. But I can see that learning how to focus the HS30 well and under a variety of different conditions might take some considerable practice before it was fully mastered.In the end I decided it was just more practice than I wanted to undertake. The Fujifilm HS30 camera simply does not work well for me for doing low-light, time-exposure photography, both because of the limits on the ISO and shutter speeds, and because of the lack of an "exposure" live view on the LCD.  Since that is my main interest, I decided to return it to Amazon.If you have different interests, then the Fujifilm HS30 camera might turn out to be one of the best Bridge cameras you have ever owned in your life.  It certainly has all the potential to be just that. I really do hope there are others who can benefit from this camera better than I did.In either case at least you now have the best information about it that I can provide you from my own limited experience with it.  I hope it was of help to you in eventually making your own decision about which camera to buy.  Whatever you decide, it should be what you decide that you like best, not what I or anyone else tells you that you ought to prefer, because each of us has our own reasons for preferring one camera over another.Best wishes to all,  John

Reviews.Title: A worthy replacement
Reviews.Author: Joms "Joms"
Reviews.Content: I will make this review as simple as possible. I will state the pros and cons of this camera over my previous HS10 and SX40 cameras.PROS- Better IQ, Dynamic Range.- Smoother manual zoom and manual focus ring.- Improved placement of built-in Flash- Much faster AF.- Much faster STS times, write times(especially on RAW+JPEG), shorter lag.- Much better EVF and LCD.- Real-time Intelligent zoom is now available unlike before where it shows useless box in HS10. Saves you time from cropping and interpolating.- Intelligent sharpness seems to work well under certain conditions especially when pictures are pixel-peep.- Longer battery life- Cheaper. I don't know why in the hell HS10 is expensive than HS30. (Hello sellers knock your head off).- Manual focus is still PITA to use but better than HS10.- A lot better in video both in AF(faster and hunting is very minimal) and zooming. Snapshot while recording is nifty feature too.CONS- This is subjective but I find HS10 color better. With a little tweaking, you can get similar color reproduction in HS30 or HS20.- Live-view is still not accurate on Manual and S-Mode.- Manual focus is still PITA to use but better than HS10.Compared to SX40PROS- Similar IQ- Manual zoom (You can zoom-in and shoot 3+ seconds faster than any motorized zoom camera).- Better ergonomics and handling- Better and has more magnification in Macro.- 58mm filters can be attached directly although you can buy $10 adapter for SX40.- Much faster and more accurate AF.- Much faster STS times, write times, shorter lag.- Much better EVF and LCD size and resolution.- For some swivel LCD is an advantage but for some titling is better and easier.- This is subjective but Fuji is better than Canon in color reproduction.- Native RAW support although you can have one in SX40 thru CHDK.CONS- SX40 optical zoom is an advantage for a very distant subject.- Optical IS is better than Sensor-shift IS.- For some swivel LCD is an advantage but for some titling is better and easier.- More expensive- SX40 video is better.- SX40 Live-view is better and more accurate.- CHDK would be a nice addition if only supported.I uploaded sample pictures in the gallery. Check also my HS30 album [...] at DPReview.Thanks,Joms

Reviews.Title: Very Good Point and Shoot Camera
Reviews.Author: DonD "Retired IT Systems Specialist"
Reviews.Content: Good:Very good build. Better than the HS-20.New lithium ion battery is very good. I have yet to run it down in a day's shooting.Excellent color and sharpness (set size to medium for ISO 100 and DR to 400).Very low noise in daylight.Good low light.Excellent Electronic View Finder (EVF).Awesome 2x digital (60x total) zoom. Actually able to shoot 60x handheld due to great Image Stabilization (IS).Focus is faster and more accurate than the HS-20.Electronic level works great and is very useful for landscapes.Intelligent sharpness works well.JPEG enhancement is excellent and usually beats my ability to process RAW files.Bad:Awful manual. Inadequately describes functions and how they work. I received most of my info/help from the Fujifilm Forum on DPReview.The HS-30 does poorly in burst mode or continuous shooting. The live view does not let you see continuous action.Conclusion:Very good point and shoot camera. Would have earned an excellent but for the poor continuous shooting and crappy manual.

Reviews.Title: My Fuji HS30EXR
Reviews.Author: stitchhappy
Reviews.Content: Such a wonderful step up from my first Fuji.  I love the added zoom capabilities, love that I can use auto/manuel settings.  I'm very happy that I can add filters to this camera and I am excited to learn all I can about this camera as time goes buy.  High quality and easy to use with unique 360 degree panoramic feature... I'm learning something new everyday.. Love it ... I'm not a camera pro but this makes me feel like one.  What I do know is my photos are better and I'm getting excited about all I have yet to learn.

Reviews.Title: HS30 EXR
Reviews.Author: Scott N. Cooksey "cookseyscott"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my wife about a month ago and have been pleased. I think I like it more than her but she has never been much of a gadget person:)  The EXR mode has seemed to do a great job in most cases, especially in bright outdoor situations.  Like most photography, you still need to take many pictures to better your chances at getting a great shot but this to me is part of the fun.  I have 3 kids (7 & 9 years old) that are VERY active.  Usually I can get a good picture of them being active after multiple shots but this seems to be my biggest struggle. I am working on learning all the details of what this camera can do and hopefully I can master the shutter proirity mode "S" to minimize some blur issues.Like many have said, when using the HS30's powerful zoom to its max you would be best to use a tripod but you can still get some good pics if you control your steady hand or lean on something.  The rechargable battery is GREAT and lasts a very long time.  We used the camera for a week and a half of casual, occasional pictures!  - but beware when the battery indicator loses one bar it will die VERY soon. Reccomended that you charge the battery every night to assure you will NEVER have a dead battery (in Li-ion batteries this is OK and will not hurt the battery)  Get a backup battery if you want complete assurance.  Make sure you get a large capacity Class 10 SD card so you will not be limited.Pros:EXR mode is handy and effective30x zoom is very handyTakes GREAT outdoor/ bright photosGREAT indoor flash photos (moving objects need to be minimal)MANY options to make that perfect picture (if you take the time to discover and learn)RAW file optionSet up like a DSLR without the priceBEST in class battery life.Nice looking cameraFeels good to hold and has professional feelCons:Still a Point a Shoot (superzoom) so don't expect DSLR results or performanceAction photos a little hard to control blur (may be something I am doing wrong)A bit pricey (but the battery life is worth the price - really)Here are a few photos I have taken. (url below)  The basket/boy was taken at 30x zoom with no tropod.  He was a little over a footbal field away (turned out fairly decent considering)[...]

Reviews.Title: Best Bridge Camera Out There
Reviews.Author: ACL
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera a few days ago.  Let me say....I have owned (and still do) the Fuji S200EXR and a Canon SX40.  This new HS30 is better than the S200EXR and the SX40.  The HS30 is a fast camera.  Writing speed is awesome and the zoom is fast, too.  Picture quality is excellent in the pics I have shot.  Color is great, without any tweaking.  The camera is considerably smaller than the prior S200EXR.  The HS30 has just about any feature you would want or need.  So many features, I probably won't use all of them.  I am an amateur photographer and would recommend this camera to anyone.  IMO, this is the best bridge camera available.  Haven't owned the new Sony 200, so I can't comment except to say I have never been impressed w/ Sony cameras.  Go buy this Fuji.  And by the way, my S200EXR is now for sale!

Reviews.Title: Great camera for last step before SLR
Reviews.Author: pbp4Katie "pbp4katie"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  I've had it for a month now & brought it to a family reunion, soccer practices, amusement park, beach & family days.  It's easy to learn how to use, but also has many manual setting options I'm learning as I go.  I love that it has some you can save to your own setting (ex. for quick action sports) & look forward to how I want to set those.  Pre-set macro settings are fantastic -- crystal clear & crisp.The only thing I haven't figured out yet is the best low-light setting when subject is too far away for the flash.Movies are easy to shoot & download.  Settings for photos and movies are very accessible through the menu.Big thing for me is how comfortable it is to hold & shoot with -- grips are in just the right spots & the weight of it isn't noticeable (which I was concerned about prior to buying).  My wrists aren't in great shape, so that means a lot to me!I bought a kit at the same time & just keep the UV filter on to protect the lens.  Haven't used the hood yet, but am grateful it was included with the camera.  Charger is slim & charges battery relatively quickly.I wasn't sure how much I would use the tilt LCD screen, but I'm finding myself using it more and more already.  It's great to be able to hold the camera at the best level & angle without contorting or kneeling -- I can also keep the attention of my subject, when needed.I expect to be ready to move to a SLR in a few years with the help of this great camera -- may be happy enough to just stick with this one, though!

Reviews.Title: After a big trip, feeing great about the camera
Reviews.Author: Philip Laube
Reviews.Content: I agonized over this purchase. I was heading on an African safari and wanted a camera to catch photos I've missed on trips before. The camera worked well. Even some complements from professional photographers about what I was able to capture. The manual zoom was one of the best feature. It was a lot easier to quickly frame my shot and capture some elusive animals.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera, but not for action photos.
Reviews.Author: LaxDad73
Reviews.Content: This camera has many great features including multiple settings such as full manual, shutter-priority and aperture priority for those who want to have more control, and the ability to use an external flash (great for indoors when you need more than the on-camera flash can do). The extra-long zoom is also a big plus along with the small easy to handle size and light weight.  However, although it says on the Fujifilm website that the HS-20-EXR (no specific mention of this on the HS-30EXR description in fairness) has "Continuous-burst shooting @ 7.6fps (16M) up to 8 frames" on the Fujifilm USA website, my photos on the HS-30EXR were almost all completely blurred and some were just blobs of the players' uniform colors.  I thought this FPS feature would be at least as good on the HS30-EXR, but I was unable to capture a lacrosse player running down the field with any clarity. My Nikon D70 did much better at the same event as I was comparing the two side by side.PS: I just tried adjusting the settings specifically to 8 fps, which is a choice on the sports settings menu, right before submitting this review and still could not get clear pictures of my son running in the yard on a very bright day at ISO 800.  In summary, lots of good things on this camera, especially for the price, but shooting action photos didn't work out for me.

Reviews.Title: for family
Reviews.Author: Biker Chick
Reviews.Content: My daughter -in-law needed a new camera...she asked me to help her get one and this is the one she wanted...she absolutely loves it...She is still learning how to use all the bells & whistles but it is taking great pictures and everyone is impressed with the photos...She started taking night pictures of the moon and you can see the craters in the moon...how awesome is that...So if you are looking for a low to middle priced camera...this is it.

Reviews.Title: A Really Good Deal
Reviews.Author: Arch Stanton
Reviews.Content: I haven't really had time to wear this one in, but here are my initial thoughts. Thus far this camera is amazing for what I paid. The price seems to have gone up since then but it's still an extraordinary deal. This approaches SLR quality yet is $2-300 cheaper than even a basic SLR. It should be noted though that this is basically the same camera as the Fujifilm FinePix HS25EXR except that that one takes AA batteries while this one has its own brand. Also, the SDHC Card on this one isn't located in the same compartment as the battery so every time you change the card the camera doesn't turn itself off. I really hate that space-saving feature on a lot of cameras these days.I'm coming onto this from a Fujifilm FinePix JZ300, which was nice except that I wore out the rubber on the zoom lens through overuse. I can tell I won't have that problem on this one since the lens doesn't move in and out every time I turn on the camera. In fact the zoom lens is adjusted mechanically by twisting it, a must for me since it allows for greater control and accuracy. This camera has a 30x lens which allows for incredible closeups. It's basically like having binoculars hooked up to the front of your camera. I was able to zoom in and make out a hawk in the distance that I just plain couldn't see with my own eyes. This incredible zoom just makes it all the more unforgivable that the camera has a plastic tripod screw. How on earth can you make a camera with a 30x zoom and not expect people to use it with a tripod?This isn't an SLR but it's close. The lens is built in and unchangeable, but it's good enough that only real pros would need a different one. It even has decent macro settings. The settings do take a little fiddling with to get them to work right. The manual isn't particularly helpful in this regard. But the automatic mode (EXR) is pretty basic to use and does a good job of determining the proper settings to take the best picture. Once you figure out how to use it manual mode works very well. Changing the aperture and the shutter speed is pretty simple and there is a manual focus dial that makes it quite easy to use. The ISO and aperture are adjusted though a dial next to the mode dial while the focus is on the lens itself. Only complaint here is that the viewscreen doesn't show you the picture you'll actually take but just the view out of the lens. That means it'll take a lot of practice to get good shots out of this. Fortunately it takes pictures really quick so you can try quite a lot of things in a short period of time.There are nine other modes to chose from but those are the only two I really bother with. Panorama mode is really cool when it works, which it usually doesn't. Having the gyroscope on is essential for this. It is rather more successful when recording a less than 360° view. I may get more use from this mode when I actually go somewhere worth getting a panoramic view of, but for now it's just a waste. I have a panoramic app on my iPhone that's a lot less finicky. Another mode takes 3d pics which seems cool but is just sort of gimmicky. Also there are two modes which are basically half of manual mode: one of which has auto aperture but manual shutter speed and the other mode has the inverse. Apart from these you're better off just sticking to automatic. Surprisingly the video mode isn't located on the dial but has its own dedicated button. This allows you to take photos while you're using the video camera. Pretty cool. It records in 1080p which is bluray quality video. It all looks pretty good. Only thing is that it only records video for 29 minutes at a time, so if you're thinking this can replace a dedicated video camera then you're gonna be disappointed. No I don't know why it won't record an even 30, it just doesn't.So, gidgets that I like about this camera: it has a gyroscope that helps you keep the camera level which is very useful for horizon shots. It flips vertically when you turn the camera on its side. There's an anti-blur feature which is useful but rarely seems to do much. It's a bit hard to tell whether it's working. Like all fujifilm cameras nowadays it features facial recognition software which works quite well unless there are multiple (or occasionally no) faces in shot.  There are USB and HDMI outputs hidden under a panel in the side which are useful for displaying your photos over a TV or computer. The other side holds the memory card and the battery in two separate compartments. I've heard people have problem with the flash, but that hasn't happened to mine yet. It does need to be manually opened and one of the more annoying features of silent mode is that it turns the flash off too. It does feature a slot on the top for an external flash which may be useful as the built in one isn't very impressive. I like having a viewfinder that I can look down but I wish it stuck out since my nose keeps rubbing against the main viewscreen. There is a light sensor next to the viewfinder that determines whether you're looking through that or using the main screen. It tends to switch back and forth whenever you move your hand so I just set it to stick on one or the other. The viewscreen has a pretty awesome feature that lets you pop it out so that you can see it while holding the camera at an angle. This hasn't come in useful yet but I'm sure it'll come in handy later. If you ever need to shoot over something this feature will be a lifesaver. The camera comes with a reasonably good strap but not with a case (at least mine didn't). You're gonna want to get one as when you have the strap around your neck the camera knocks back and forth against its viewscreen.Most of the minor problems are pretty minor. There is no way to charge the battery without removing it or to plug the camera in and use it though a wall outlet. Some of the controls are hard to figure out. The zoom is so powerful that you can easily zoom too far and get blurry photos if you don't watch out. And as previously mentioned the tripod screw is made of plastic and will not last. But aside from that it's a really excellent device. I'll be updating this over time as I get a better feel for it's capabilities, but thus far I've had no problems. A good buy.

Reviews.Title: Beyond excellent
Reviews.Author: T. Dengler
Reviews.Content: This is an awesome camera.  Yes, I know there are some that complain about this camera.  I truly believe many of them just hate any camera that isn't Nikon, Canon, Minolta, or any of the other fashion units.  My guess is many of these same folks are waiting for their Iphone5 because they are terribly disappointed with the Iphone4.  I've been an amateur photographer for some 45 years and have used all of the top name camera's, and this camera is a great camera that takes remarkable pictures and is relatively easy to use.  Of course it helps to have a working knowledge of basic photography skills, but anyone having those skills will get great results using this camera.  I still use a high end 35mm SLR and a newer DSLR, but I find I use the Fujifilm HS30EXR much more than I ever thought I would. I would recommend this camera to anyone looking for a mid-range bridge or a general all purpose camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: oldmotem "kevin"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera from a non-Amazon source.  However,  the price was right.  I've always wanted a camera and lens combo that was small and light.  I've been photographing with various Canon and Nikon DSLRs for years.  I have an early model Olympus (C-8080) that I still love.  That camera is a forerunner of all these new "mirrorless" cameras.  The HS30 is a vast improvement on that old model Olympus.Best points:  Lens.  Only one.  Don't have to change lenses.  Don't have to carry heavy telephoto lenses up those long trails.  Don't have to change lenses while out in dirty conditions so there's no problems with getting those nasty dirt spots on the image sensor. I hate cleaning off image sensors.  And hate even more getting dirt spots off photos with editing tools.Light and compact.  It's smaller than any other camera I own (except the one built in to the smartphone which doesn't autofocus anymore).Autofocus.  The smartphone's is broken.  But the autofocus on this HS30 is GREAT.  Fast,  precise.  I try to take photos of the stars at night with my DSLRs.  Good luck.  Forget autofocus.  And the manual focus?  Try looking through a tiny viewfinder at night.  I have.  It doesn't work.  The HS30 can focus on the moon easily and most of the time on the stars even in a dark area of the sky.  Nice.Manual focus.  FAR better than anything I have on my DSLRs.  You get a blow-up of the image on the LCD screen and you also get a lit-up yellow slider with a floating white dot at the end.  Turn it until you see best focus (it's hair trigger so go slowly) and you should also see the white dot slide to the right maximally along with the yellow slider.  It takes a little practice,  but it's very do-able.  Far better than focusing through a tiny viewfinder on a DSLR.Tons of exposure modes and manual mode as well.  It has all the standard modes (PASM) as well as those wonderful EXP and a lot of other auto-modes.  I very often use EXP in high resolution mode with ISO 100 to get some really great shots.  Exposure is varied depending on what you point the camera at.  Auto-compensates for bright objects and auto-exposes with manual override for exposure under or over the norm.  Very nice.Battery.  I have several.  I change them about once every week or two.  And I take LOTS of photos.  The battery lasts for many 100s of photos.  Maybe 1000 or more.  Amazing.  I bought extras on Amazon along with an included cheap charger.  They work fine.Negatives:  Sometimes if I flick the camera off and then on right away,  it won't go on.  I just flick it off and wait about 5 seconds and turn it on again.  No problems after that.  The ISO button is beginning to lose its letters from being pressed so often to look at the photos on the LCD (the ISO button is the zoom-in button).  Not really a problem.  This is a high use device so I expect some wear.This is not a negative:  It's just that when you use this camera you forget when you zoom in you really have to be a photographer and remember to use a tripod or else stand VERY STILL.  Or put the camera on something and use the remote trigger.  Zooming in causes blur quite easily when zoomed in far.  But this is the case with ANY camera zoomed in far.There aren't too many negative things to say about this camera.  Mine works fine.Things I like a lot:  PANORAMIC VIEW.  Practice with this.  It's GREAT!  You can get a beautiful vista photograph (panograph) much more easily than by taking multiple photos and stitching them together in photo editing software.  You do get some stitch artifacts at times,  but you can get some great 120 to 360 degree photos with this camera.EXP:  That auto mode with its submodes has gotten me some wonderful photos!MACRO: It works great.  Extreme close-ups of flowers,  or whatever.Super-MACRO:  Even CLOSER photos of flowers,  or whatever.The Lens:  It's not a $5000 Canon or Nikon lens.  But I don't have the money to buy those lenses anyway.  For the cost of this camera,  you won't even get a lens from  Nikon or Canon that zooms anywhere near what this lens can and for its quality.  There is not too much wide angle curvature (I have other lenses on DSLRS that have worse).  The lens takes great photos from wide to nearly zoomed in fully.  And when zoomed in fully it takes very good photos IF you use a tripod.  It does sometimes have auto-focus issues when zoomed in fully.  It takes more time to focus in that mode.  I just zoom out a little.  Then the focus is much easier.  I rarely use any telephoto on full zoom in anyway.Overall,  for the price I paid and for the photos I've been able to get with this little camera,  it's been well worth owning.  I've had it since mid-October and have taken well over 10,000 photos with it.  Nice.I want another one.  Just to cover the time when this one (if it does) someday wears out.P.S.  It shoots video too.  I haven't really done much of that.  Too busy with still photos.  There are other reviews in here about shooting at night (star photos) and the lack of longer than 30 second exposures.  ISO 100 at 30 seconds is what you get.  ISO 200 and about 15 seconds or so.  Etc.  Someone else has that info in his review here on the site.  I have been able to get some really nice 30 second star shots with this camera on a tripod and the remote trigger.  Or else use the 10 second delay timer.  It's also excellent for moon shots.  You don't need more than about 1/100 second or so for the moon anyway.The main difference between this camera and an expensive DSLR with $5000 lens is the slight grain you get when you blow up photos to 2 feet by 3 feet or so.  The DSLR will have less grain.  That's not a big deal for me.  This camera on ISO 100 gets some really GREAT photos!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Facundo Pezzi "facucat"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a friend of mine during a trip. The condition was that i get to use it during the my trip. i was surprised by the light weight of the camera. System speed is amazing, you practically turn it on, and you're set to go. You can control absolutely everything, ISO, f, exposure, graininess, etc. The screen is moveable, maybe not as much as i like, but is just enough to take pictures if you are holding the camera up high or down low.Battery life is very good. Has internal memory, but i bought a 64GB sd card (you can't go wrong on this one).Sunsets and night pictures look amazing, colors look vivd.Overall a very very nice camera for less than 300 dollars.

Reviews.Title: Outperforms Many DSLR's
Reviews.Author: ProSound
Reviews.Content: Just picked this up at Costco for $249.  Came with 8GB card and protective case through them.  This camera is amazing, you can absolutely get close in on all types of subject matter and they focus in clean and tight and can get some awesome Macro results.  For plain wide angle shooting, its as good as some of the $800+ offerings out there too.  The 1808P video capture is amazing with this lens.  You can film birds and other animals that would normally jet off just by your presence and it looks as if you were right next to them.  Awesome camera for a very competitive price.  There are ALOT of controls on this camera.  If you are used to simple point and shoots this camera may be overwhelming.  The EXR auto modes pretty much do all of the quick shot thinking for you, but in some cases the decisions the camera makes in low light conditions are not the best.  There isnt really anything bad I can say about this camera considering it blows everything in this price range out of the water.  It is bulky, but your dealing with a 24-720mm lens and if you think your gonna keep light with that setup, your mistaken.  It is much lighter and more compact than anything with a comparable lens.  I always use Canon or Nikon for digital photography but Fujifilm has a real contender now.  Those who think Fujifilm is cheap need to reconsider and give this camera a serious look.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Val
Reviews.Content: It is not a DSLR but it has great capabilities.  I love that it shoots in RAW and I can also do HDR photos with it. I love Fuji film and I can choose to use the many different controls to vary my photos! I was surprised to learn that its CMOS is a bit larger than on the Cannon PowerShot SX40 HS. I like that I can manually control every aspect if I desire.Picture quality is fantastic. You may need to touch some things up.  Low light is not real great, but the flash works well for indoors.The Panoramic shot feature is great fun and well worth using.

Reviews.Title: Best choice bridge camera for me !
Reviews.Author: Cathy
Reviews.Content: Threaded for 58mm filtersExcellent EVF and LCD; can turn off LCD to save battery, or set so LCD switches to EVF when eye moves to EVFHot shoe for external flash if built-in flash is not powerful enoughManual zoom (faster and more accurate than motorized and doesn't use up the battery)Manual focus available1080HD stereo 320FPS video with dedicated on/off button...choppy if using manual zoom in/out (remember, it is primarily a camera, not a camcorder)Can take a picture while recording a videoRated 600 pics per battery charge in P-mode/no flashMacro down to 1cmRAW and/or JPGUp to 30 second exposureMain settings available via dedicated buttons, rather  than having to go into menusExternal charger includedManual available as PDF (print and bind at Kinkos or view on your phone or tablet)...not just HTML which has to be viewed on computer24mm-720mm optical = 30X zoom (can be doubled to 60X with digital zoom)EXR mode = super intelligentElectronic level display available for horizon alignmentMini-HDMI to HDMI output available for playback on your TV (cord not included)Multiple burst modesTilt (not articulating) LCDGreat ergonomics with grippy rubber coatingMultiple exposuresPanorama (120-180-360 degrees)..sideways or up/down...works best on a tripod3D modeFace tracking, face recognition, face detection...auto shutter releaseDog/cat face detection...auto shutter releaseWired remote available OEM or non-OEMA little larger than other current competitors...fujifilmusa.com/products/digital_cameras/s/finepix_hs30exr/specifications/Wish List:GPSMetal (not plastic) tripod adapterAccessories Included:Li-ion battery NP-W126Battery charger BC-W126Shoulder strapUSB cableA/V cableLens cap and Lens cap cordCD-ROMOwner's manualLens hoodOverall:Is it "perfect"...no... but for me, the closest I could find !!!Soooo many features ... amazing value !!!DO NOT get the CaseLogic DCB-304 case suggested by Amazon ... it is TOO small...the camera will fit with difficulty ...but needs something a little larger.

Reviews.Title: From macros to mega zoom, this is an exceptional camera
Reviews.Author: J. Robinson
Reviews.Content: My primary interest is wildlife, and especially birds. So the long zoom is essential.The EXR 1/2" sensor is what sets this camera apart from other mega zoom cameras in this price range. Because of the way the pixels are arranged, it can take higher quality photos at 8 MP, rather than lower quality photos at 12 or 16 MP.  Trust me, 8 MP is still plenty of resolution, it's the noise (especially false colors) that destroys a photo, not the resolution.The1/2" sensor is a little bigger than many other mega zoom cameras, but not as big as DSLR sensors.  This means that the image quality is a little better than other cameras in this class.  But since the size of the lens is directly proportional to the size of the sensor, the lens isn't a foot long.  It's a good compromise.EXR Hi ISO low noise (S/N) mode combines pixels to form "super pixels" to reduce noise .  This adds a fuzzyness to the images when looked at up close. But this is less objectionable than noise.This mode does not allow digital zoom. But it does allow you to take "snapshot" photos in low light where others would fail.EXR Resolution Priority mode lets me set the ISO, and maintains a 16 MP picture and allows for digital zooming. This is my favorite EXR mode for long zooms in good light, especially where I might have to crop later.EXR Dynamic Range Priority splits the pixels in two, such that half of them fire at higher sensitivity and half at lower sensitivity, simultaneously .  It then combined the two images to produce an8 NO picture that brings out details in shadows while not washing out bright area of the picture.  This mode disables flash, and overrides the ISO I set. But it does allow for digital zoom.EXR Auto not only selects one of the above EXR modes, but may also select a "scene" mode, such as beach, portrait, or landscape. It may also select a macro mode, or even the "Pro Low-Light" mode. It senses whether there is a face in the scene, or a moving subject, and adjusts accordingly.Pro Low Light is one of the "advanced" modes.  It will take 4 frames in rapid succession and layer them to bring out detail and reduce noise. This is very impressive, but requires a still subject and a still hand (or tripod). Since it fires the shots at 11 frames/second, the overall exposure time is still only about 1/2 second, but that is still too much time for a moving subject.  For example, it will take four shots at 1/8 second, f/5.6, and ISO 3200 to produce an OK image, where at ISO 400, and f/5.6, the shutter would be 2 seconds.  1/8 second is hand-holdable.  2 seconds is not.It is still a challenge to get a good crisp, image in very low light, but it is significantly better than hand held ISO 3200. It sometimes also produces a darker image, which makes sense since the camera knows that it is a dark scene.One of the characteristics of small sensor cameras like this is that they have an exceptionally deep depth of field. This means that the subject matter and the background are often both in focus. This can be a good thing, if that's what you're looking for, but some times, you want the background to be out of focus so that the subject "pops". Another advanced mode of the HS30 is called "Pro Focus Mode". This actually takes two photos. One with the subject (and often the background) in focus, and one with the background out of focus. It then merges the 2 photos to leave the background out of focus. I'm not sure how the camera chooses what is to remain in focus, and what is not, but so far, it has done a pretty good job.One of my favorite modes is called "Natural & Flash". This takes two photos in rapid succession. The first without the flash, and the second with the flash.ISO 200 has pretty good S/N and allows better speed than ISO 100. That's probably the best default, except for very bright conditions. ISO 400 starts introducing noise, but it really isn't that bad.The flash is surprisingly powerful, but depletes the battery. Buy extra batteries.  It is also extremely fast. I have used the built in flash strobe to stop the the wings of a humming bird in flight.The battery charger that comes with the unit comes with a 3' cord, which is a bit cumbersome when traveling. I recommend buying batteries and a charger that plugs directly into the wallGenerally speaking, it selects a high ISO too often. I suspect because the most common complaint is picture blur caused by camera shake. But maybe I'm being too critical here. Noise in ISO 400 isn't that bad. I may be looking closer than I should. I haven't printed any hard copies yet for a side-by-side comparison.Another feature that sets this camera apart is the manual zoom ring on the lens barrel. This functions much like the zoom on a traditional SLR.  It is much faster and precise than the typical lever and motorized zoom.  More about that, and it's short comings later.The camera has two "intelligent digital zoom" levels 1.6X, and 2.0X. I find that the quality of the 1.6X digital zoom is excellent, and indistinguishable from the optical zoom alone. The 2.0X zoom does start to degrade image quality, but still very usable.It seems that none of the other flash manufacturers provide TTL flash units for Fuji.  So if you want TTL you'll have to go with a Fuji Unit.  They seem like good reasonably priced flashes, but they don't produce a ring flash.Manual Focus:The manual focus ring is my greatest disappointment with this camera,  because it is not physically coupled to the focus mechanism, but rather a controller for the focus motor. This means there is a slight lag as you are focusing, resulting in over-shooting your intended focus point and having to back track.Also, the focus "meter" shown on screen tells you if what it thinks should be in focus is in focus, not the focus distance. This is pretty much useless because I'm usually using manual focus because the camera doesn't know what to focus on in the first place (the branches in front of the bird, or the bird). It also doesn't tell you if you need to bring the focus in or out, so there is a lot of fidgeting.Since the focus ring is just free-spinning, there is no stop when you are focused on infinity or nearest focus. When looking through the viewfinder at a blurred image, you don't know whether you are focused in too far, or out too far, so you have to try spinning the ring in both directions until your subject is in focus, and once again the focus lag hinders this. While this system is superior to the typical point and shoot manual focus system (with a toggle lever), it could certainly be much better.Using the AE/AF lock button (below the movie button) to force an auto-focus even when in manual focus mode is very helpful, and makes up for the above shortcoming.This is a solid (ie relatively heavy) camera. Still lighter than a DSLR, but still a substantial weight. As such, the large grip with a protrusion for your thumb is very ergonomic, as are all the controls.

Reviews.Title: Best Digital Camera I  ever Had!!!
Reviews.Author: Circus Circus "Ken"
Reviews.Content: Fujifilm FinePix HS30EXR Digital CameraThis is my first Review ever of any Camera on AMAZON or on any site. I read a lot all the Comments and discussion in this site and in others as well about the EXR Fuji Family, before I jumped in and bought  this HS30-EXR Camera 03 months ago. I come from the CANON world since 10 years ago and I have no doubt whatsoever this is the best Camera I have had of all the ones (Canon - SX1-IS, SX20-IS and SD980-IS) I had before. I am an Amateur in this world of Phothography and I have practiced a lot with this Camera and read the complete manual thoroughly. Is not an easy Camera to learn, I can tell you that. But this Camera gives you so many possiblities and Modes and settings, that is almost impossible, after you learned it, to take bad Photos with it! This is an exceptional, well built and very Practical camera. I know many of you think and believe this is an awfull, badly built and very difficult to learn Camera!!. Not so. You have to dedicate time, practice a lot and read many, many Blogspot, Sites and reviews, to really start to get a grip on this Camera.I am very happy with it and I paid a very low price for it, so that makes it sweeter to me. I sometimes shoot Raw and PP using the bundle software that came with my Camera. But mostly I shoot out mainly in JPG's on Family meetings, my grandkids parties and plays on playground with them. Also I shoot  Landscapes and take lots of movies with it and I think they are outstanding quality. From all the 2000 shots I have taken, probably I have thrown out 200 shots and that to me is an outstanding miracle because most shots have been taken on moving and playing with kids around. With all that in mind, I have no doubts to recommend and praise a lot this Camera HS30-EXR and will encourage anyone thinking on buying a good, solid and pratical Bridge, day to day camera that will last you many, many years!!!. Cheers...."UPDATE" (01/09.2013)I continue to enjoy this Camera a lot on all my shoting outings. I have enhanced the use of the Camera by adding some very useful add ons: 1) DSRL Kit Radio Flash triggers and Yongnuo YB-560-II Flash and YN-460-II Flash units, 2)Fotodiox SoftBox Kit, 3) Neewer Led Light(160 led fro Movies) CN-160, 4) Hoya UV(O)S-HMC Filter and KENKO Digital CPL MC (Polarizer Filter)5) Leather hand Strap. All of this accesories are helping me a lot with Portrait Photography, Night Movies and more complex and Professional shots. I can not tell you how happy and truly sattisfied I am with this camera. Get if you can. You will not regret this investment.Aaron...

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm HS30EXR
Reviews.Author: Theodore S. Bernardi "Scott B."
Reviews.Content: Best camera I've ever owned.  Basically, it's got the features of a digital SLR in a smaller format, so you get the great zoom range without having to change lenses or have something that sticks out two feet in front of the camera.  My first experience with it was hiking up on a ridge trail near where I live and getting some awesome telephoto shots on a clear day overlooking our town and the Sacramento Delta. I used a monopod, and the pis were sharp and the colors vibrant.The controls are laid out well; there are a lot of extra buttons dedicated to things like setting AutoFocus mode, Exposure compensation, ISO, video, white balance AF/AE lock, continuous mode shooting so you don't have to dig down into menus.An electronic viewfinder was a must for me. I take a lot of landscape shots, and LCD's are very hard to see in bright sunlight. It automatically senses when you bring it up to your eye and switches to EVF.  The tiltable LCD screen is a great feature also.The EXR modes have some really cool features - like taking multiple shots at different exposures and combining them to extend the dynamic range.I like that the zoom is controlled by rotating the lens barrel just like on an SLR. You can also set it to manual focus via rotating the barrel.  The lens has threads so you can use filters, polarizers, etc.Battery life is very good. I'm still on my first charge.  In my previous cameras I had shied away from rechargables because you always had to make sure it was charged before you could grab your camera, and if you are out in the woods and your battery runs out, your hosed.  I did buy an extra battery, only cost me $8.It is bigger than my previous camera (Olympus SP-565).  This is pretty much the size of a digital SLR

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix HS30exr
Reviews.Author: Robert J. Cyr "upnorthbob"
Reviews.Content: This is a bridge camera with a 30x Zoom (24-720mm) with great image stabilization.  A great walk around camera for someone who doesn't want to carry a DSLR and several lenses.  The EXR mode works well and enhances the capabilities of this cameraby analyzing the scene, light value, subject, etc. and takes great pictures.  The lens is a manual zoom which reduces battery drain, with the rechargeable battery, Fuji claims 600 shot per battery charge.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera for this price!
Reviews.Author: Maggie
Reviews.Content: I should start by admitting that I am a point-and-shoot kind of gal. I had a great camera several years ago with all the bells & whistles (lenses,etc). I dropped it out of a tree (while taking some amazing shots) and irreparably damaged it. I've stuck with inexpensive cameras since. I treasure my pictures too much and have finally decided that I need a "real" camera again. I was hoping to find something right in the middle. Good zoom and macro, not too heavy, etc. My biggest issues with my basic Canon and nikon point-and-shoots were that I wanted more optical zoom and I hated that pics taken in low-light were always terrible. I have not begun to learn about most of the options on this camera, but straight out of the box (on the basic settings), I have already taken great macro, zoom and low light photos. I especially love that I can get great pet pics without the eye issues.This camera is a decent weight and convenient to carry, but still takes quality photos and video. Best of all, it cost about half of what I expected to pay!If you need a bridge camera, this is a great deal.

Reviews.Title: WOW
Reviews.Author: Nancy Sheehy
Reviews.Content: This camera is more than I expected. We are older and really like to take pix but dont have the patience for all the detail in DSLR photo taking.  This is a perfect blendng of the 2. Pointy and shoot ease when you want it, with DSLR quality.  Manual control w3hen you want.. GREAT BLENDING of the 2 ! Now we don't need to bring both.. P&S; for quickies and DSLR for quality! YEAH !

Reviews.Title: Perfect cam for dentists
Reviews.Author: David
Reviews.Content: Awesome cam. I am dentist and this cam is  just what I need for my clinical cases. Good macro and definition.

Reviews.Title: Fujifilm FinePix HS30EXR Digital Camera
Reviews.Author: Kelly Garton "KellKell"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! I have no professional experience but I was able to take professional quality pictures on my first attempt. The camera has so many bells and whistles that the bigger names have...but not the BIGGER price. (THANK YOU AMAZON for the GREAT price!) This camera had a 3D mode, a 'cat' and 'dog' mode, portrait, live action...OMG there is so much to this camera I would be here all night writing. I took some professional pics of my daughter and son in law at a park and when I posted them on Facebook, everyone thought they were taken by a professional. The best part of the camera is the screen that is adjustable. Its just an awesome camera for the non-pro like myself. I have definitely found a fun and exciting hobby!

Reviews.Title: Decent superzoom camera purchased through Amazon
Reviews.Author: Timothy L. Worcester
Reviews.Content: This is second superzoom from Fuji that I have owned.  HS30 has many great improvements that made the 720 enticing.  Great for outdoor scenery and grandkids summer sports.  Still does not have the low-light capability of an slr.  This took great family portraits and outstanding scenery at a family reunion in Yellowstone NP.

Reviews.Title: Overall love it - few limitations
Reviews.Author: LAM
Reviews.Content: Purchased the Fujifilm FinePix HS30EXR for the extended zoom and RAW format option.  I have been using Nikon SLR/DSLR for a long time.  Overall I like the HS30 - wanted the RAW format option, zoom photos good and definitely close with the 720mm equivalent, macro photos good.  Only drawback so far is the continuous shots rated at 5 FPS are slower to write to the card (using a 32 GB Class 10) than my Nikon DSLR.  Am still able to change ISO, aperture, shutter speed when desired, good scene options.  Taking both cameras to Alaska.

Reviews.Title: Getting Used To a FASTER camera
Reviews.Author: L. Walker "Feather Forestwalker"
Reviews.Content: Am certainly enjoying how absolutely *fast* this camera is.I am not up on all the terms, but I did notice that the ISO settings are a bit differently accessed in this camera than in the HS20 I have. I replaced my HS20 with the HS30EXR due to a heavy scratch on the lens, but when I got the HS30EXR I also purchased some filters; the clear one will double as a lens protector; I am often in locations where scratches on the lens become unavoidable, so a new habit ensues; BE MORE CAREFUL (I am SUCH a clutz, LOL).I am looking forward to trying out the video as well as other newer features on this camera; so far I am **very** happy with it.Planning to spend time reading the manual and really getting to know this camera better. Keeping it clean this time is a MUST.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Lino
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera that can take great pictures. Love the manual zoom much easier and quicker to use than the auto zooms on most of the bridge cameras. Love the feature set. I have not run into a single situation so far that I could not get excellent pictures in as long as I was willing to learn to use the camera settings available. You can take almost any picture in any situation without having to add anything additional to the camera.  Awesome Camera can't say enough good things about it.

Reviews.Title: Really like this HS30EXR
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: This is a fantastic camera. I had a Fujifilm S5100 for the last 8 years and I loved it. The improvements they made on this HS30EXR was far beyond I would have thought they could have added all in one camera. There are features I have not even tried to use yet because the EXR mode does such a fantastic job. The movie option is really great also but you have to use a tripod when you zoom in to get a good stable video. All in all I am glad I made the decision to purchase this great camera. I know I will have many years of enjoyment with this camera.

Reviews.Title: very good camera at this price
Reviews.Author: Yasar Kalay
Reviews.Content: This camera has variaty of automatic settings. Manual mode is what I expected. The aparture, shutter speed and ISO can be chosen manually. The only negative is manual focusing. It doesn't feel like analog style focusing.

Reviews.Title: hs30exr
Reviews.Author: saeed
Reviews.Content: Viewfinder not very clear, very pixilated. Zoom ring is not smooth, quite stiff. Buttons on left side very handy and makes for easy changes. Quality of pictures very good for a low cost entry level camera.

Reviews.Title: Very good, versatile
Reviews.Author: Daniel Baboiu
Reviews.Content: I ordered this camera impressed by its high zoom and macro capabilities, as well as its image stabilization, allowing handheld shooting at high zoom. But when it came, I was even more impressed.  I pushed it to the limits, and apart from its known limits in low light (e.g., longest exposure time depends on ISO settings, probably to limit noise level, a side effect of small pixel size), it was quite good.  I used it for tiny details on leaves in supermacro to tiny details on the Moon (well, relative speaking...)There is very little that a true DSLR can do that this camera can't. True DSLR's have larger pixels and possibly longer exposure times at high ISO. The other part is changing the lens - I can't put this on my telescope, but with the high focal range, this camera is pretty much all you need (unless you're in truly extreme photography).Full manual control, including for focusing, add to its value.My only regret is not buying an extra battery. Even with its large capacity, you might find yourself wanting more. I got 550 shots on a single shot, but also with a lot of time spent framing at different zoom levels and even using the flash, this is really close to the rated maximum capacity of 600 photos.

Reviews.Title: Very good
Reviews.Author: derick
Reviews.Content: This is a very good Camara and the image quality is outstanding if you are looking for a Camara that is at a good price but want the pro image and feel this is the one .

Reviews.Title: Incredibly fast and great image
Reviews.Author: MtnTeacher
Reviews.Content: Very good camera and incredible manual zoom with larger sensor that has made some great images at the Dew Tour in Breckenridge. I was shooting 11 fps and every image is sharp and the low light has incredible depth ans detail. AWSOME>

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money!
Reviews.Author: Nancy
Reviews.Content: I can't write enough good things about this camera. I am picky about electronics, but was very surprised with this camera. It has features that are easy for anyone to use. The camera itself feels like a very quality piece of equipment. I was looking for a camera with good zoom capabilities and this on has it and more. To think I nearly paid a LOT more for a camera that didn't have the features that this one does and this is a lot easier to use. I am not a beginner with taking pictures, but I am also not even close to a professional. The Fujifilm FinePix HS30EXR is an amazing camera and I would recommend it to anyone. My sister-in-law loved it so much she has also purchased one.

Reviews.Title: Great buy!!
Reviews.Author: Italo La Posta "Roman One"
Reviews.Content: This camera is loaded with options and is built well. I am not a professional photographer or reviewer of cameras so I will keep this basic. You can turn it on, point and shoot and end up with great pics or you can take the time to learn how to use it and take better pics. Either way you win.

Reviews.Title: fuji camera review
Reviews.Author: Doc
Reviews.Content: It took great pictures right out of the box. Took great pictures while on vacation in Alaska. Performed beautifully. Once We got home and viewed the pictures on the camera, everything was fine. Then suddenly, about 2-1/2 weeks after I recieved the camera, it locked up and would not advance to the picture taking mode. It would only display on the LED screen to turn off the camera and try again. It also had a picture of a small camera in yellow with an exclamation mark. I repeated the turning off as requested again and again with no improovement. I then contacted Buy Dig.com and made arrangemnets to return the camera for a refund. The camera is still in transit and they were very accomadating on the telephone. Hopefully, the return process will finish smoothly.

Reviews.Title: Great bridge camera
Reviews.Author: Regina
Reviews.Content: I got a used version from the Amazon Warehouse. Though it mentioned light cosmetic damage, I don't even see it. I've been testing this camera for two days now and it's taken really great photos both indoors and outdoor.

Reviews.Title: Excellent except for noise
Reviews.Author: William A. Fuller "The Old Bald Dude"
Reviews.Content: Fuji did everything right with this camera except the images are way too noisy, even in the low noise EXR mode or at ISO 100 (lowest available ISO). I can get rid of the noise up to ISO 400 in either Lightroom 4 or Nik's Dfine 2.0 without noticeable degradation in picture quality, but it's an extra step in processing that would be better handled by a better sensor. Beyond ISO 400 the camera is essentially useless.Otherwise, there are a lot of good things to say about this camera. Very little distortion even at the widest angles available. Lots of manual control and enormous flexibility. It's very light, but solidly built. I really like the manual zoom. Much easier to use than the motorized zoom in most cameras in this price range. The electronic viewfinder is surprisingly good. Controls and menus are well laid out for quick access to the settings you need to use most frequently.The only other issue is speed. It takes a long time to record an image and be ready to shoot again, especially if you are shooting RAW. The software supplied for RAW processing is terrible, but Lightroom 4/Adobe Camera RAW handles it just fine.Battery lasts a really long time, and third party spares are inexpensive and excellent. Charging time is about 2 hours.I bought the camera because I need the super zoom and manual controls in a lightweight package and it fits that need very well except for the fact that the images are always too noisy. If the noise performance was better, this would be a 6 star out of 5 deal. As it stands, though it's clearly a 3. Usable, but slightly annoying.

Reviews.Title: Noisy, soft pictures
Reviews.Author: E. Barber
Reviews.Content: I tried every mode on this camera and took over 300 pictures with only 3 or 4 being relatively decent after processing out the noise and fixing the exposure in Light Room.  I couldn't believe how grainy and noisy the photos were from this camera.  I was sorting through some old pictures from an old 5 MP HP I had over five years ago and these pictures were much better than the ones with the brand new, expensive camera that is supposed to be excellent.  Nope.  Not at all.  The face recognition mode (and dog face mode) took soft, even blurry, pictures and the auto release was too slow to even catch the face shot anyway (in one instance catching two tails instead of faces), I do better on my own.The only reason I did give it two stars is that I LOVE the manual zoom and the way the camera feels in my hands.  The tilt screen is also a nice feature.  These points made me sad to have to send this camera back and I tried really hard to make it work for me.  You have no idea how much I really wanted to like this camera.  I tried hard to attribute it to user error and "figure it out."  It was not me.  I did so much research on different settings to try and how to reduce noise.  Eventually, after trying everything I could find and reading many reviews about others with problems with noise and soft focus, I concluded that it was not me.  If only the image quality was acceptable, I would never have traded this camera for anything.If you're not really picky about image quality and noise, this is probably a very nice camera, I just can't handle it.Overall, extremely disappointed.  I had high hopes for this camera.  I don't think that clear pictures with minimal noise is too much to ask without having to go to the inconvenience of DSLR.  Yes, I am extremely picky, but I have had cheaper cameras in the past that made me happy, so I am pleasable.  I just want pictures I am proud to have taken, not embarrassed to share!  I sent it back today.  I guess I'll spend a bit more and try the Panasonic Lumix FZ200 and hope it does better!

Reviews.Title: Fuji HS30 EXR Great Enthusiasts Camera
Reviews.Author: DFSTARMAN
Reviews.Content: I tried the Nikon 510 and the Canon HX 40 and returned both.The FUJI has many more features than the other  and much better build quality.It also has a 58 mm thread so you can add filters or a teleconverterImage quality is good but it is an enthusiasts camera not for someone that just wants point and shoot.Manual is quite good as these things go.I have compared images with it to my canon S100 and Sony Alpha 65 and I am quite happy with this cameraThe only thing I didn't like is that it does not have true live view like my other cameras and the exposure meter in manual mode is bit touchy it reads the scene one way them when you push the shutter half way down it jumps to something a bit different and the exposure meter is not graduated it is  just a line and you have to estimate where the middle is.

Reviews.Title: So far so good!
Reviews.Author: Renee Aubuchon "reneesarah"
Reviews.Content: Unboxed today, and unfortunately it is raining, so no outdoor photographs today!  I added the double image of the dragon and the lady above to give an example of the double exposure feature.  I have the HS 10 and have been shooting with it for a couple of years.  It is not a DSLR and it is never going to be- it is a bridge camera.  I also have an expensive pro camera and I will tell you how often I use it: never.  It is heavy, bulky, and does not have much of a zoom lens on it.  I have used the HS 10 all the time because it is light weight, has a great zoom lens on it, takes entirely decent photographs and I can easily take it anywhere.As the saying goes- the best camera you have is the one you take with you and use.Out of the box today I can see that the HS 30 is a big improvement over my HS 10.  For one thing, it will shoot in RAW or RAW plus JPEG.  That is awesome.  Also the zoom is threaded (58 mm).  That means I can slap a teleconverter lens on it if I don't think I already have enough zoom.One of the things I really like about bridge cameras like the HS 30 is that you can let the camera make the decisions for fast shooting, or you can do manual override and make the decisions yourself.I like the small form factor.  That means I will really use this camera.  The grip is very comfortable for my woman's hand.Nikons and Canons in this classification were also rans for me.  I would be able to get longer zooms elsewhere, but early reports said the image quality with the competitors was not quite as good.  Since image quality is very important, I decided that if I wanted a longer zoom I could thread on a teleconverter.The included software to view photographs didn't work with my Mac Powerbook, but that is a non-issue since I have other photo editing software I use and really like.So just out of the box today: so far so good!  We'll see what happens when we get some sunshine around here again after the rain and I am able to get out and do some outdoor shooting.  I will report back!

Reviews.Title: Photos not as good as Canon
Reviews.Author: Tiga
Reviews.Content: I compared with SX40HS and sent it back. I was hoping the higher magnification and resolution viewfinder and manual zoom would be plusses, (which they were) but in practice it was very slow to start up (the fast start up function doesn't actually let you take pictures!), focus was unreliable at tele end, and the combination of  image stabilization, focussing and processing just produced inferior picture quality in most cases and a lot more unusable images or missed shots. Another paradox was that the viewfinder seemed low on the CPU priorities, so some pictures would be OK, even though the finder hadn't caught up and still seemed blurred when shooting...

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: David E
Reviews.Content: This is one of the easiest to use cameras I have owned. Amazon and FujiFilm have a real winner here. I received the camera before the estimated arrival date, and was out taking pictures after a short period of charging the battery.  The pictures both inside and outside are perfectly light balanced without using a flash I must say. I am really impressed with this camera.Fujifilm FinePix HS30EXR Digital Camera

Reviews.Title: Capable of fine results, maybe disappointing if used only on "auto."
Reviews.Author: Ken
Reviews.Content: I use this almost exclusively for nature photography, chiefly botanical.  I live on a farm in an extremely bio-diverse environment in Colombia and needed a highly portable, versatile camera for both macro and extreme telephoto shots as opportunities arose.  This camera has filled my need although not without a learning curve and experimentation.  I have used it nearly every day for the past 11 months. Macro and extreme tele both give excellent results.  Nature photos taken on "automatic pilot" often do not turn out well.  The camera heavily over-exposes; fortunately the exposure compensation and bracketing controls are convenient because I use them in nearly every shot.  The electronic viewfinder is just a little better than no viewfinder at all but is functional once you get accustomed to dealing with its delays and erratic lighting.  It is a necessary feature here where LCD screens often blank out.  The tilting LCD is useful for getting shots at odd angles although when tilted up to the 90 degree position, it apparently sometimes confuses the EVF sensor and turns off the screen so you have to regroup and try again.  This is not a fast camera.  It is rarely useful for bird photography.  I have not tried many of its features because I don't need them.  I chose this model because I am a fan of Fujifilm products and especially of the color rendition of Fuji digitals.  It has not let me down in that respect.  Has it been worthwhile?  Eminently, because of hundreds of usable photos I have taken with it that I would have missed otherwise by having the wrong camera or no camera at all when the chance came.  I don't doubt that I could have been equally happy with a different camera, color rendition being equal.  It doesn't replace the DSLR either; my Fuji and Nikon DSLR's still get frequent use.  For my purposes it has been excellent.  Would I recommend it?  It's now an outdated model so I would look for a more recent version if buying now.  The used price is down around $200 I believe and it should be a good value a that, worth trying out to see if it fits your particular needs if you're out for a super-zoom. Several hundred photos I have taken with this camera can be seen at http://www.flickr.com/photos/21586985@N07/page1/

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera with Large Zoom Range
Reviews.Author: Hugh Hunkeler
Reviews.Content: This camera is fantastic! It replaced a much older FujiFilm camera, and the additions in features are huge. The photo quality is better, low-light performance is better, and the automatic functions have improved. I specifically wanted a camera with a hot shoe for a separate flash, a long zoom (30x), and one with anti-shake, which this one has. It uses a proprietary battery rather than four AA cells, which turned out to be an advantage. I got two spare batteries and an additional charger, so there will always be one or two fully charged spares. The official Fuji batteries are pricey, but I got the spares + charger from a non-brand-name place here on Amazon.
